snippet.title: Time, Space, and Cosmos in Mesoamerica | Dr. David Tavárez - Tiny Lectures
snippet.description:
Zapotecs in Northern Oaxaca created sophisticated calendars to help keep track of the passage of time. More than one hundred Zapotec manuals were turned over to colonial administrators and provide rich detail about ritual practices—an unusual collection of indigenous manuscripts, not found anywhere else in Central America. 
Created with support from Humanities Texas, the state affiliate of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

snippet.title: The First Ghost Stories | Dr. Irving Finkel - Live Events
snippet.description:
Learn how the near-universal belief in ghosts goes back to the beginning of time.  Discover how the oldest known writing, in cuneiform script on tablets of clay, gives us a full picture of the ancient Mesopotamian ghost experience: who might be expected to be a ghost,  how to keep the dead happy in the netherworld, how to banish annoying ghosts that keep appearing and how to summon the dead to come back and disclose the future.

Thanks to the Iraqi American Community for their support in sharing this event. 
Created with support from Humanities Texas, the state affiliate of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

snippet.title: Tiny Lectures: Memorial Murals | Amy C. Evans & Israel McCloud
snippet.description:
AMY C. EVANS is an award-winning artist, writer, and documentarian based in Houston, Texas. She holds a BFA in Printmaking from the Maryland Institute College of Art and an MA in Southern Studies from the University of Mississippi. Amy built the documentary program at the Southern Foodways Alliance, headquartered at the University of Mississippi, where she served as their lead oral historian for more than a decade. Her latest project is “Houston in 2020: Self-Employed Black Artists” and is funded by a grant from the Houston Arts Alliance. Amy’s first book, co-authored with Martha Hall Foose and published by Chronicle Books, A Good Meal Is Hard to Find: Storied Recipes from the Deep South, was released in April 2020 and is being celebrated as "one of the most unique art volumes this spring [that] doubles as a cookbook." 

AMY’S WEBSITE: https://www.amycevans.com/
ISRAEL McCLOUD’S WEBSITE: https://www.israelmccloudstudio.com/

TITLE: MEMORIAL MURALS
Amy C. Evans is an award-winning artist, writer, and oral historian whose most recent project is “Houston in 2020: Self-Employed Black Artists,” a multimedia project documenting the impact of current sociopolitical, economic, and cultural factors on five Black artists in the Bayou City. Meet one of those artists, Israel McCloud, a 4th-generation muralist and sign painter who believes that he has a responsibility to use his work as a mechanism for change. Three of his most recent murals were created in the summer of 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic,  and are documents of violence and injustice, pain and loss. His work is part of a long tradition of artists memorializing significant cultural events in community spaces.


Follow Archaeology Now Houston
http://archaeologynow.org/
https://www.facebook.com/ArchaeologyNowHouston/
https://twitter.com/archaeologyhou

snippet.title: Tiny Lectures: Stalking Prehistoric Dartmoor | Win Scutt
snippet.description:
Stalk the moors of Dartmoor where hundreds of enigmatic stone circles, stone rows, cairns, cists, and round houses show human activity during the Stone Age and Bronze Age.  What was their use?  Some structures are still a puzzle.  Win Scutt, with English Heritage is your guide to these amazing sites.

To discover more about the Merrivale site, check out this link:                                                     https://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/merrivale-prehistoric-settlement/history/

You can learn more about the mission of English Heritage here:  
www.english-heritage.org.uk

snippet.title: Tiny Lectures: Mysterious Göbekli Tepe - Dr. Mehmet Ozdogan
snippet.description: Older than the pyramids. Older than Stonehenge. The mysterious site of Göbekli Tepe in Turkey arose over 14,000 years ago and contains some of the most magnificent artifacts from a revolutionary period in humankind’s development that lead to the creation of agriculture and settlement. Why was it built? Discover more as Dr. Mehmet Özdoğan, renowned Professor Emeritus from the University of Istanbul reveals the latest information about this glorious site where speculation and fact converge.

snippet.description:

snippet.title: The Tale Behind: Donkeys - Dr. Carolyn Willekes
snippet.description:
Nacho, the donkey, gets his day in the sun!  The object of jokes, considered stubborn, contrary, and untrainable, nonetheless, the donkey has been an important part of our lives.  Dr. Carolyn Willekes helps you discover why this essential animal became such an object of mockery.

snippet.title: Tiny Lecture: Archaeology of Thirst - Dr. Michael Fuller
snippet.description:
Quench your thirst for knowledge!  Discover how the ancients sated their thirst in a time before fluoridated water, wine with sulfites, and pasteurized milk. Dr. Michael Fuller takes us through his research and excavations to shed light in a fascinating examination of the history behind modern day delights that make our lives much more pleasant.

snippet.title: Tiny Lecture: Virtual Access to the Ice Age - Dr. Dominique Rissolo
snippet.description:
Take a deep dive into the Ice Age as Dr. Dominique Rissolo introduces exciting new interdisciplinary scientific advances that reveal previously elusive information about the ancient world, allowing archaeologists to explore sites that were once inaccessible.  Dr. Rissolo is Assistant Research Scientist at the Qualcomm Institute at the University of California, San Diego and co-leads the Cultural Heritage Engineering Initiative (CHEI).

You can learn more about Hoyo Negro project below!
http://hoyonegro.ucsd.edu/

Read more about their dive into Hoyo Negro here!
https://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/feature/diving-for-the-bones-of-the-ice-age

Get in touch with Dr. Rissolo via drissolo@ucsd.edu

Follow Archaeology Now Houston
http://archaeologynow.org/
https://www.facebook.com/ArchaeologyNowHouston/
https://twitter.com/archaeologyhou
https://bit.ly/2XfhcFl

About Dr. Dominique Rissolo
Dominique Rissolo is an assistant research scientist at the Qualcomm Institute at the University of California, San Diego and co-leads the Cultural Heritage Engineering Initiative (CHEI). He has worked closely with multiple agencies and universities to plan and execute oceanographic research projects using autonomous, remotely operated, and human occupied vehicles as well as vessels for scuba operations. As an archaeologist, Rissolo’s interdisciplinary research focuses on ancient Maya and Paleoamerican cave and cenote use as well as paleocoastal human ecology and the development of ancient maritime trade networks along the Yucatan coast. Rissolo has been actively involved in the development of workflows for the visualization of image-derived data from marine and underwear sites and has enabled collaborating researchers to expand the visual analytics capability developed by CHEI and the Jacobs School of Engineering at UC San Diego.

snippet.title: The Tale Behind: Dogs - Dr. Carolyn Willekes
snippet.description:
Our next installment of our biweekly Monday blog posts about animal/human interaction introduces a new video element: The Tale Behind! These short segments enrich the material found in the online blog. Today, Dr. Willekes and a special guest star discuss evidence for the development of emotional bonds between humans and dogs.

snippet.title: Tiny Lecture: Chefs of Monticello - Dr. Leni Sorensen
snippet.description:
Dr. Leni Sorensen is a culinary historian and a PhD expert in 18th- and 19th-century cooking methods used by Virginia housewives and slaves, including those who cooked for Thomas Jefferson.  Previously, she was the African-American Research Historian at the Thomas Jefferson Foundation, Inc., Monticello. Most recently, Sorensen was named “Virginia Female Chef” by USA Today in their article “50 States – 50 Female Chefs.”

snippet.title: Tiny Lecture: The People of Roman London - Dr. Sadie Watson
snippet.description:
Discover the multicultural nature of Londinium, a Roman city on the current site of the City of London.  Archaeologists are discovering that, as a major trading center, the city was host to visitors from around the Roman world, creating what must have been a vibrant culture.  

Dr. Sadie Watson, affiliated with Museum of London Archaeology (MOLA), is currently undertaking a four-year Future Leaders Fellowship: Measuring, maximizing and transforming public benefit from UK Government infrastructure investment in archaeology', focusing on ensuring that public spending on archaeology leads to meaningful and relevant research and genuine community participation. She came to this project after more than 20 years in the field, directing excavations throughout the City of London, with a specialization in Roman London. 

Dr. Watson was Director of the Bloomberg Excavations, a three-year project that has been termed "the Pompeii of the North" because of its significant preservation of innumerable artifacts revealing life in Roman Britain.  Sadie was the guest of Archaeology Now in 2015 when she gave many talks to to over 1,500 students in Houston area schools. 

Our grateful thanks to Dr. Sadie Watson for her time and generosity. Be sure to follow her using the links below. 
https://www.mola.org.uk/people/sadie-watson
https://twitter.com/drsadiewatson

snippet.title: Tiny Lecture: Feasting Like A Pharaoh - Dr. Salima Ikram
snippet.description:
We are excited to kick off our new mini-lecture series with an extraordinary talk from world-renowned Egyptologist, Dr. Salima Ikram. 

Dr. Ikram is a Professor, Archaeologist and Author. She is also the leading expert on animal mummies. As a founder of the Animal Mummy Project at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, she has emerged as one of the leading scholars in Egyptian funerary archaeology. 

During the video, Dr. Ikram included the fascinating factoid that Egyptians invented barbecue! She has kindly included that recipe which you can view below.

http://archaeologynow.org/dr-salima-ikram

Our grateful thanks to Dr. Salima Ikram for her time and generosity. Be sure to follow her using the links below. 
https://www.salimaikram.com/
